title: 115_hr1728
content: BOUNDARY MODIFICATION, MORLEY NELSON SNAKE RIVER BIRDS OF PREY NATIONAL CONSERVATION AREA, IDAHO. In this section, definitions are provided for key terms related to the Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area, including Conservation Area, Gateway West, and Map. The curr_chunk provides definitions for key terms related to the Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area, including "map," "sage-grouse species," and "Secretary." It also outlines the modification of the Conservation Area boundary to include additional land. The Conservation Area boundary is modified to include approximately 4726 acres of land depicted as "BLM Administered Lands" on the map. These lands will be managed by the BLM Jarbidge Field Office until terms of the Stipulated Settlement Agreement are met, after which they will be managed by the Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area office. The Conservation Area boundary is modified to include approximately 4726 acres of land managed by the BLM Jarbidge Field Office until terms of the Stipulated Settlement Agreement are met. Additionally, approximately 86 acres of land depicted as "BOR Administered Lands" will be managed by the Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area office. The exclusion of approximately 761 acres of land, including the Gateway West Transmission Line route, is also specified. The Gateway West Transmission Line will be sited close to the existing Summer Lake Transmission Line, with Segment 8 no more than 500 feet away. Segment 9 Revised Proposed Route includes approximately 1,845 acres of land for the Gateway West Transmission Line. The Secretary will issue a right-of-way to Gateway West for the construction and maintenance of transmission lines, including access roads and fire prevention activities, within 125 feet on either side of the center line of the Gateway West Transmission line. The Secretary will issue a right-of-way to Gateway West for construction and maintenance of transmission lines, including access roads and fire prevention activities, with conditions aligned with proposed routes for segments 8 and 9. Conditions will comply with the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. Gateway West must mitigate impacts related to transmission lines during construction, following the Compensatory Mitigation and Enhancement framework. Costs for mitigation and enhancement should not exceed $8,543,440. Additionally, Gateway West is required to contribute $2,000 per acre of right-of-way for conservation efforts. Gateway West must contribute $2,000 per acre of right-of-way in the Conservation Area during the construction of Segment 8 and Segment 9 Revised Proposed Route to the Bureau of Land Management Foundation for conservation purposes. The Landscape Conservation System Units in Idaho, also known as National Conservation Lands, will have costs associated with boundary modifications covered by Gateway West. The Secretary will administer the lands in accordance with the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976. The Secretary will administer lands in Idaho as part of the Conservation Area and National Landscape Conservation System. Administrative jurisdiction over 86 acres of land is transferred from the Bureau of Reclamation to the Bureau of Land Management. The jurisdiction over 86 acres of land is transferred from the Bureau of Reclamation to the Bureau of Land Management. A map will be available for public inspection, and a management plan amendment will be made within 18 months to address long-term management activities and uses of the lands in the Conservation Area. The management of lands in subsection (b)(1) aims to determine appropriate activities, continue livestock grazing with regulations, and allow motorized access on existing roads. The Secretary will allow motorized access on existing roads and hunting/fishing on lands in subsection (b)(1) with reasonable regulations and policies. The Cotterel Wind Power Project area on approximately 203 acres of Federal land is prohibited from being used for wind electricity production. The Bureau of Land Management Foundation is addressed in the following section. The Secretary of the Interior will establish a Bureau of Land Management Foundation as a nonprofit corporation to address specific challenges with the support of a foundation. The Bureau of Land Management can address challenges with the support of a foundation, including reclamation of legacy wells, sustainable management of wild horses, responsible development techniques, voluntary conservation activities, and identification of cultural treasures on public lands.
